results.title: [Australian olympic team visits Bayer works at Leverkusen on June 22nd 1936]
results.brief_description: Documentary from 1936 about the visit of the Australian Olympic team to the Bayer Works, manufacturers of Bayer Aspirins and APC powders, at Leverkusen, near Cologne, Germany before travelling to Berlin for the Olympic Games. The Australian Olympic team are shown arriving in Cologne, Germany, and being met by representatives of the Bayer works. They move on to a casino where they have breakfast. The team’s chaperone, Mrs. Ferguson talks to long distance runner, Daryl Backhouse. At the Bayer Works factory team members Alf Watson and Pat Norton look at a machine which fills and caps vials. The team moves on and looks at a machine which makes Bayer aspirins. At a dock on the Rhine river, where raw materials for the factory are unloaded, team members L. Cook, Duncan Gray and Bill Dixson are shown standing around and chatting. After a visit to the factory the team are shown sight seeing around Cologne. Shots of a booklet signing are followed by shots of Berlin. As the Australian team disembark from their train on their arrival at a railway station in Berlin, the German Navy are shown playing ‘God save the King’ on the station’s platform. Words of the sound film are spoken by Mr. Alderson, manager of the Australian Olympic team.

results.title: [A New map for Canada]
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge, John H. Tyo, Robert Anderson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
This film is a survey of Canada in terms of its national air service. Far below a Trans-Canada Airlines (T.C.A.) passenger plane, the new map, a continent wide, unrolls, patterned with high mountains and orchard valleys, prairies with their rectangular grainfields, the Great Lakes and the eastern farmlands. One T.C.A. flight soars over Cleveland and New York; another service crosses Québec and the Maritimes; while a trans-oceanic air liner heads out across the broad Atlantic.
Title and credits missing.

results.title: 'round and 'round
results.creator_credit: Barbara Greene, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: When Alex Lawson, minister, came to Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan, he recognized the need for a family self-help program. In cooperation with his parishioners, he organized the Minto Family Life Education Program. Through group meetings, they are learning new skills to help them restructure their lives and resolve personal problems. Though the people participating in this program live in a small Prairie town, their concerns are universal, like raising children, adolescence, loneliness, marital strife and alcoholism.

results.title: 'E'
results.creator_credit: Brent Walker Film Productions, Robert Forget and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Under the guise of a pretty fairy tale, this animated film makes a strong political statement. Paper cut-outs enact a drama in which a dictator, suffering from a visual defect which affects his perception of things, imposes his delusions on his unfortunate subjects. The humour is black and despite an absence of dialogue the message is clear. (Awards: Berlin, Cracow, Zagreb, Gijon, Barcelona, New York)

results.title: 'Colleges classiques' in Quebec
results.creator_credit: Pierre Patry, Leonard Forest and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Founded on a study of the humanities, the classical colleges of Quebec have no exact counterpart elsewhere. This film explores their origins and shows how the classics still open the door to the wisdom of the ages. However, changes are being introduced, including greater emphasis on the sciences.

results.title: Zvenigora
results.brief_description: Zvenigora is a complex yet compelling fantasy, presenting the story of a group of Russian peasants and their strong ties with the earth through a series of simple yet strikingly beautiful images. Spanning a period of a thousand years, the film relates the eternal struggle between needing to nurture the land and wanting to strip it of its treasures. A wealth of magical images fill and frame the landscape, from the wizard monk whose death-like countenance terrorises the invaders to the man who advertises his own suicide as theatrical entertainment then absconds with the box office takings. This film is as much a parable about human nature as it is a representation of the struggles of the Russian peasantry, using technical experiments similar to those of Georges Melies to embellish the transcendental nature of the subject. Zvenigora is the fourth film by Russian film master Alexander Dovzhenko, who began his career in film in 1926 after working as both a cartoonist and painter. Despite negative critical reaction to Zvenigora, it was the forerunner of his more celebrated films Arsenal (1929), Zemlya (1930), and Ivan (1932), which perpetuated his interest in honouring the lives and struggles of peasants, and served as a tribute to his heritage as a man of the Ukraine.

results.title: Year of the Dogs
results.creator_credit: Michael Cordell and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Football is a game capable of inspiring incredible emotional responses from both players and supporters. Michael Cordell captures the highs and lows of the 1996 season as seen from players and two loyal fans. Key players are followed through their injuries, as are the politics of management. What emerges is a team of players and supporters united by their love for the game and the Footscray Football Club.

results.title: We of the West Riding
results.creator_credit: Ken Annakin, Ralph Keene and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: Yorkshire, its people, factories and wild moorland scenery. We are shown the country in which the Bronte sisters were born and its influence on their famous novel. Finally the chorus of the Chapel Choir sings the Hallelujah Chorus from Handel’s “Messiah”.

results.title: Wanda
results.creator_credit: Barbara Loden and Foundation for filmmakers
results.brief_description: A remarkable one-off from Elia Kazan’s wife. Shot in 16mm and blown up to 35mm, it’s a subtly picaresque movie about the wanderings of a semi-destitute but aimless American woman. Directing herself, Barbara Loden manages to make the character convincing in her directionless amorality, yet gradually sympathetic and even heroic. Essentially a road-movie with an existentialist backbone, the film depicts Wanda drifting into desultory relations with a bank robber, to whom she becomes attached despite his unpredictable temper. But Wanda botches everything and fails to deliver the getaway car after getting lost in a traffic jam. The story continues with our last glimpse of her back on the road, being picked up in a bar. Similar in feel to other contemporary films, “Two-Lane Black Top” and “Killing of A Chinese Bookie”, “Wanda” refuses to provide explanation or judgement of its characters and delivers a picture of both intimacy and tragedy. A neglected masterpiece of American independent film-making. Regrettably the director/star produced nothing else before her untimely death from cancer.

results.title: Walking
results.brief_description: An artist’s observation of the way people walk. Ryan Larkin (Syrinx, Cityscape) employs a variety of techniques - line drawing, colour wash, etc. - to catch and reproduce the motion of people afoot. the springing gait of youth, the mincing step of the high-heeled woman, the amble of the elderly - all are registered with humour and complete individuality, to the accompaniment of special sound. (Awards: five awards, including Salerno and an Oscar nomination)
